title: Optometry Vocabulary
description: Focus your attention on this quiz about the specialized terminology of eye care professionals.

questions.question: What is 'myopia'?
options: Nearsightedness, where distant objects appear blurry

questions.question: What does 'astigmatism' refer to?
options: An imperfection in the curvature of the cornea or lens causing blurred vision at all distances

questions.question: What is 'presbyopia'?
options: Age-related difficulty focusing on close objects due to loss of lens flexibility

questions.question: What does the 'retina' do?
options: Controls the size of the pupil
Protects the eye from UV light
Contains light-sensitive cells that convert light into electrical signals sent to the brain
Produces tears to keep the eye moist

questions.question: What is a 'slit lamp'?
options: A lamp with a cracked shade
A type of laser used in eye surgery
A reading lamp for eye exams
A microscope with a bright light used to examine the structures of the front of the eye in detail

questions.question: What does 'diopter' measure?
options: The optical power of a lens, indicating its light-bending ability

questions.question: What is 'glaucoma'?
options: A group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, often related to elevated eye pressure

questions.question: What does 'visual acuity' measure?
options: The width of your visual field
How quickly your eyes adjust to darkness
The sharpness and clarity of vision, typically tested with an eye chart

questions.question: What is 'hyperopia'?
options: An excessive number of eye floaters
Farsightedness, where close objects appear blurry

questions.question: What is 'tonometry' used to measure?
options: Intraocular pressure (the fluid pressure inside the eye)

questions.question: What is a 'cataract'?
options: A clouding of the natural lens inside the eye that affects vision
An abnormal growth on the eyelid

questions.question: What does 'pupillary response' refer to?
options: The constriction and dilation of the pupil in response to light changes

questions.question: What are 'progressive lenses'?
options: The most advanced type of contact lens
Multifocal lenses with a gradual transition from distance to near vision without visible lines
Lenses that slowly darken in sunlight

questions.question: What is 'amblyopia' commonly known as?
options: Lazy eye, a condition where one eye has reduced vision due to abnormal visual development

questions.question: What does 'refraction' test determine during an eye exam?
options: The exact lens prescription needed to correct your vision
